Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Photonic Crystal Based Spectrometer for Manufacturing Process Control
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project investigates the development of an inexpensive ultra-compact optical spectrometer. The photonic crystal spectrometer uses the leaky modes of photonic crystals patterned on a multimode waveguide to selectively extract wavelength specific light to a two-dimensional detector array. This pattern can be analyzed to reconstruct the spectrum. The photonic crystal spectrometer's geometry scales in a fundamentally different manner from a diffractive grating spectrometer. Three significant differences in the operation allow this device miniaturization. First, light interacts along two dimensions in the photonic crystal array, allowing waveguided light to be distributed through a waveguide plate, shortening the optical path. Second, wavelengths can be resolved along two dimensions, allowing the use of a two-dimensional photodetector to achieve spectral separation, shrinking the detector size. Lastly, resolution is a function of the photonic crystal array elements employed, not the separation between the diffractive element and detector. The goals of this project are to develop a miniature spectrometer prototype using a low-cost imaging module, and to achieve improvements in range and resolution through redesign of the photonic crystal array. The anticipated result of this project is a low-cost broadband spectrometer physically smaller than any commercially available comparable device.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project lies in the applications where size and/or cost are critical. Commercially available optical spectrometers cost at least $1000 with a minimum volume of 200 cm3 and as a result cannot penetrate markets where size and/or cost are critical. The anticipated cost of the new photonic crystal spectrometer is under $100, with a potential size below 1 cm3, allowing the use of these devices in applications such as on-line process monitoring, solid state lighting characterization and testing, emissions control, portable sensing, and health care. Pollution control applications, for example, will have the potential for significant broader impact through on-board optimization and monitoring of combustion systems, allowing a measurable improvement in environmental impact, while process monitoring, such as on-line spectral monitoring for nanocrystal synthesis, will enable greater oversight in nanomanufacturing, increasing the quality of nanomanufactured materials used for solid state lighting and reducing waste.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project investigated the development of the photonic crystal spectrometer, an inexpensive ultra-compact optical spectrometer. A spectrometer is an analytical instrument which measures the spectral content of light, or color. They are important components in systems where color or wavelength provides direct information, such as analysis of lighting and color matching in printing, interior design, and cosmetics. Spectrometers are also important components in systems where color or wavelength provides indirect information in chemical analysis applications in chemistry, biology, geology, and medicine. Commercial applications include integrated or portable/hand held devices for industrial process control, emissions testing, lighting analysis, color matching, public health, security, and health care.

The photonic crystal spectrometer uses arrays of holes smaller than the wavelength of light to create photonic crystals, which interfere with light at specific bands of wavelengths. An array of photonic crystal patterns on a waveguide is used to create a 2D map of the wavelengths of light in the waveguide. A camera takes a picture of the map which is analyzed to determine the spectral content of the light. The regions on the map can be as small as a few microns or as large as millimeters. The goal of this project was to improve the performance of the photonic crystal spectrometer and develop a compact prototype module for testing.

A compact module was prototyped with a volume of less than 1”×1”×0.5”. This compact module was successfully demonstrated in a limited channel test analogous to a commercially relevant application. The projected bill of materials ranges from $43 for a broadband module down to $26 for a limited channel module, compared to >$1000 for grating based spectrometers. The photonic crystal spectrometer provides a unique benefit to many applications through its potential for both low cost and small size. This technology addresses a new cost segment of the spectrometry market, between expensive grating spectrometers and inexpensive dye filter arrays. The method of operation allows for application specific channel customization. The small form factor offers a unique degree of versatility for integrated applications, allowing spectrometers to be included in small spaces for compact and handheld instruments. Modeling performed during this project predicted that the device could be miniaturized to less than 0.75mm thick, enabling highly integrated applications currently unrealizable with commercially available competing technologies. 

Using the results of this project, Chromation is currently developing a module for evaluation in a limited channel commercial application.
